Vse manj Hrvatov hodi k maši
04 Nov 2019, 15:00 by STA

Na Hrvaškem je lani le nekaj več kot 22 odstotkov vernikov redno hodilo k maši, kar je skoraj deset odstotnih točk manj kot leta 1999, je pokazala raziskava, ki so jo opravili v okviru projekta o raziskavah evropskih vrednot na Hrvaškem. Raziskava je pokazala, da se je skrčilo tudi zaupanje anketirancev v Cerkev kot institucijo.



Fotografija je simbolična. Foto: LEO CAHARIJA

ZAGREB > Na Hrvaškem obstaja visoka raven konfesionalne in religijske identifikacije, saj se je lani več kot 80 odstotkov državljanov identificiralo z določeno versko skupnostjo, kaže projekt, katerega nosilec je teološka fakulteta iz Zagreba.
Znanstveni prispevek z naslovom Med distancirano cerkvenostjo in intenzivno osebno religioznostjo: Religijske spremembe v hrvaški družbi od 1999 do 2018 sta pripravila profesorja zagrebške pravne in filozofske fakultete Siniša Zrinščak in Krunoslav Nikodem.
Med verniki je bila manj kot polovica takih, ki se imajo za zelo religiozne, medtem ko večina navaja, da imajo svoj lasten odnos z Bogom in lasten način življenja religioznosti.
Na Hrvaškem je bilo lani 80,3 odstotka deklariranih katolikov, 0,9 odstotka pravoslavnih vernikov ter 0,2 odstotka pripadnikov islamske vere.
Medtem ko število vernikov ostaja relativno stabilno, se je občutno zmanjšala institucionalna praksa. V primerjavi s podobnima raziskavama, ki so ju izvedli v letih 1999 in 2008, se je zmanjšalo število vernikov, ki se redno udeležujejo maš. Tako je leta 1999 31,4 odstotka vernikov redno hodilo k mašam, lani pa se je njihovo število skrčilo na 22,6 odstotka.
Manj je tudi vernikov, ki občasno obiskujejo maše. Lani je bilo 12,3 odstotka vernikov, ki vsaj enkrat mesečno gredo k maši, medtem ko jih je bilo leta 1999 21,1 odstotka. V enakem obdobju se je skoraj podvojilo število vernikov, ki sploh ne hodijo v cerkev, in sicer z 10,4 odstotka leta 1999 na 19,6 odstotka lani.
Občutno se je znižalo tudi zaupanje v Cerkev, saj vse več vernikov meni, da ne daje ustreznih odgovorov na moralna in socialna vprašanja kot tudi vprašanja iz družinskega in duhovnega življenja. Skoraj 63 odstotkov vernikov je leta 1999 kazalo zaupanje v Cerkev, medtem ko je lani Cerkvi zaupalo 38,4 odstotka vernikov. Število tistih, ki nimajo nobenega zaupanja v Cerkev, se je zvišalo s 5,1 odstotka leta 1999 na 20,8 odstotka lani.
Religiji so bolj naklonjene ženske, osebe z nižjo izobrazbo ter osebe, ki živijo na podeželju. Istra, Reka, Zagreb in severni del države so manj religiozni kot Slavonija in Dalmacija.
text:
Fewer Croats go to Mass
04 Nov 2019, 15:00 by STA

In Croatia, just over 22 percent of believers attended Mass on a regular basis last year, which is almost ten percentage points less than in 1999, according to a survey conducted by the European Values Research Project in Croatia. The survey found that respondents' confidence in the Church as an institution also decreased.



Photography is symbolic. Photo: LEO CAHARIJA

ZAGREB> There is a high level of confessional and religious identification in Croatia, as more than 80 percent of citizens identified themselves with a particular religious community last year, according to a project led by the Zagreb Theological Faculty.
A scientific paper entitled Between Distinctive Churchism and Intensely Personal Religiosity: Religious Changes in Croatian Society from 1999 to 2018 was prepared by professors at the Faculty of Law and Philosophy, Siniša Zrinščak and Krunoslav Nikodem.
Among the believers, less than half were considered to be highly religious, while most stated that they had their own relationship with God and their own way of living in religiosity.
In Croatia, 80.3 percent of declared Catholics, 0.9 percent of Orthodox believers, and 0.2 percent of the Islamic faith were in Croatia last year.
While the number of believers remains relatively stable, institutional practice has declined significantly. Compared to similar surveys conducted in 1999 and 2008, the number of believers who regularly attend masses has decreased. Thus, in 1999, 31.4 percent of the faithful regularly attended masses, and last year their number dropped to 22.6 percent.
There are also fewer believers who occasionally attend masses. Last year, there were 12.3 percent of believers attending Mass at least once a month, compared to 21.1 percent in 1999. In the same period, the number of non-church-goers almost doubled, from 10.4 percent in 1999 to 19.6 percent last year.
Confidence in the Church has also decreased significantly, as more and more believers believe that they do not provide adequate answers to moral and social questions as well as questions from family and spiritual life. Nearly 63 percent of believers showed confidence in the Church in 1999, while last year, 38.4 percent believed in the Church. The number of those who have no confidence in the Church increased from 5.1 percent in 1999 to 20.8 percent last year.
Women, people with lower education and rural people are more favored by religions. Istria, Rijeka, Zagreb and the northern part of the country are less religious than Slavonia and Dalmatia.
